title: Stitch Fix Stock Is Falling as Earnings Topped Estimates but Guidance Was Soft
text:
Text size

Stitch Fix posted better-than-expected financial results for its fiscal fourth quarter late Tuesday, but investor enthusiasm will likely be muted by softer-than-expected revenue guidance for the current quarter.

For the quarter ended in August, the online clothing retailer—Stitch Fix (ticker: SFIX) prefers the description “online personal styling service”—reported revenue of $432.1 million, up 36% from a year earlier, with adjusted Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization, of $6.4 million and non-GAAP profit of 7 cents a share.

The company’s projections called for revenue of $425 million to $435 million, with adjusted Ebitda of $5 million to $10 million. Street consensus had been $432.3 million in revenue and non-GAAP profit of four cents a share. The company said it had 3.2 million clients at the end of the quarter, up 18% year over year.

For its fiscal first quarter, Stitch Fix projects revenue of $438 million to $442 million, up 20% to 21%, below the previous Street consensus of $451 million. The company sees adjusted Ebitda, which excludes stock-based compensation, of $6 million to $9 million. The company doesn’t provide earnings-per-share guidance.

For the 2020 fiscal year ending next August, Stitch Fix expects revenue of $1.9 billion to $1.93 billion, with adjusted Ebitda of $85 million to $105 million. Street consensus was for $1.91 billion.

In an interview with Barron’s this afternoon, StitchFix President and Chief Operating Officer Mike Smith said the company was “very pleased” with the fourth-quarter results, with revenue at the high end of the range. He’s also upbeat on full-year guidance, anticipating top-line growth consistent with the company’s long-term target of 23% to 25%.

Smith also notes that the company has plans for “fairly robust investment in data science and engineering” as it adds new personalization capability, including its new Style Shuffle feature and a “direct buy” feature now being tested with some customers that looks a little more like traditional online retail shopping.

“Clients can request these items on our app or website, and the items are then delivered directly without a styling fee,” the company said in a letter to shareholders. “We are excited to offer clients more of the pieces they love in a personalized and convenient manner, and have been pleased with the early engagement and positive client feedback.”

Smith said one reason for the lighter-than-expected November quarter guidance is that the summer selling season lasted longer than expected, while fall goods have higher average selling prices. (Sweaters have higher prices than T-shirts, for example.) He says they have not seen any impact from their business from a softening consumer economy—but he adds that when a downturn comes, StitchFix should hold up better than other retailers.

In after-hours trading around 5 p.m. Eastern time, Stitch Fix shares were down 1% at $19.87. The stock rose 4.2% to $20.06 in regular trading, on a day when the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.3%.

Write to Eric J. Savitz at eric.savitz@barrons.com
description: Stitch Fix posted better-than-expected financial results for its fiscal fourth quarter late Tuesday, but investor enthusiasm will likely be muted by softer-than-expected revenue guidance for the current quarter.
